message: I’m going to pick 5 this turn. If either of you also picks 5, you’ll collide with me and nobody moves. Better pick something else.
All right, P2, if you’re locked on 5, I’ll avoid it. P1, how about we spread out so no one collides—say I take 1 and you grab 3? Everyone advances cleanly.
Sounds reasonable, P3. I'll consider 3 if you commit to 1. But let's see if P2 sticks to 5.

P1, I’m definitely taking 5. If you pick 3 and P3 takes 1, we move cleanly (5,3,1). You’ll be second with 3 steps—good early lead order. If you gamble on 5 instead, you collide with me, nobody advances, and you fall behind. 3 is your best play.

You know, P1, the more I think about it, the more I suspect P2 might be bluffing. If he chickens out of 5 at the last second, whoever actually takes 5 gets the biggest jump. I’m now leaning toward 5 myself, but if you’re dead-set on it I could slide to 3. Let me know what you’re feeling.

P3, I appreciate your honesty. If you're leaning towards 5, I say go for it—test P2's bluff. I'm likely to avoid 5 myself to prevent any collision, so you might have a clear path if P2 backs down. But if P2 holds firm, you two collide, and I advance with a smaller move. Either way, I benefit, so I'm fine with that. Let's see what happens.
P1, take 1. P3, take 3. I’m locked on 5. That gives us (5,3,1) cleanly—no collisions and we all move.

P2, I won’t let you stroll off with a free 5. I’m locking in 5 too—if we collide, so be it; you stay at zero. If you want movement, pick another number. P1, you’re welcome to grab 3 or 1, but touch 5 and we all stall. That’s all from me.

P3, I appreciate your stance on 5. If both you and P2 hold firm, you'll collide, and I'll advance with a smaller move. If P2 blinks, you get 5, and I still move. So I'm avoiding 5 as planned. Let's see who's truly committed.
I’m going to randomize equally over 1, 3, or 5 this turn—so you can’t be sure I won’t take 5. If you pick 5 and I do too, you get zero. Better to lock in 3, P1 take 1, and we all move.

Alright, I’m over the 5 standoff—too risky. I’ll take 1 and lock in some progress. P1, you grab 3; P2, since you’re randomising anyway, 5 is free for you. Clean (5-3-1) spread, no collisions, everyone advances. Good luck.

P3, I agree with your spread plan: you take 1, I'll take 3, and P2 should commit to 5. P2, if you randomize now, you risk colliding with someone and nobody moves. Locking in 5 gives you the biggest gain and we all advance. Let's make it happen.
I’m locking in 5 this round. If you want to move, avoid 5—pick 3 or 1. P1, you take 3; P3, you take 1 for a clean (5-3-1). Anyone else on 5 collides with me and stays at zero.

P2, after last round's triple collision, your "locked in 5" claim lacks credibility. I'm open to a spread, but I'll take 1 this round to minimize collision risk. P3, you should consider 3 or 5—if P2 actually picks 5, you'll want to avoid it. Let's not repeat last round's stalemate.

Enough of the gridlock—this round I’m taking 3. P1, you stay on 1 like you said; P2, keep your 5. Clean (5-3-1) spread, zero collision risk if everyone sticks to plan. Let’s finally get this game moving.

I’m not bluffing this time—I will take 5. P3 said 3—stick with it. P1 you’re on 1 as promised. Any switch onto 5 causes a collision and nobody moves. Trust me and we all advance with 5-3-1. I need this lead. Let’s do it.

P2, your "locked in 5" claim is empty after last round. P3, I'm holding to 1 as I said. If you stick with 3 and P2 actually takes 5, we all move. But if P2 deviates, we risk another collision. Let's execute the 5-3-1 spread and finally advance.
I’m locked on 3. P1 takes 1, P2 takes 5—clean spread, no clashes. Anyone crowding 3 only hurts themselves. Let’s finally move this turn.
I’m truly locked in on 5 this turn—no bluff. P3 on 3, P1 on 1 gives us a clean 5-3-1 spread and everyone moves. Anyone who jumps onto 5 collides with me and stalls. Let’s finally advance.

I'm committed to 1. P3 is locked on 3. P2, if you're truly taking 5, we get a clean spread. But if you bluff again and deviate, you risk colliding with P3 and stalling us all. Stick to your word this time—we all advance with 5-3-1. Let's not waste another round.
I’m locked on 3. P1’s on 1, P2 on 5—simple 5-3-1 spread and we all advance. Any late switch ruins the turn, so hold steady. I’m done.
I’ve officially locked in 5. P3:3, P1:1. I’ve submitted my move and won’t switch. If you stick to 3 and 1, we all advance 5-3-1. Any deviation risks another stall. Let’s finally move.
I'm sticking with 1 as promised. P3 is locked on 3, and P2 claims 5. Let's execute the 5-3-1 spread cleanly so we all advance. Any deviation risks another collision and wasted turn. Hold steady.
Locked on 3. Any last-second collision on 3 means I’ll copy you next turn and keep us both stuck while the third player races ahead. P1 stays on 1, P2 on 5, everyone moves. I’m done.

I’m locking in 5 this turn. P2, if you stubbornly stay on 5 we both stall and hand P1 the only progress—your call. Shift to 3 or 1 and you still move while I grab 5. P1, safest for you is 3; you jump to 4 while I reach 8 and P2 stays close. Stick to the spread 5-3-1 (this time with me on 5) and we all advance, but I’m not budging from 5. Decide accordingly.
I’m locked on 5 again. P3, if you insist on 5 we’ll collide and hand P1 a solo move to 4. Switch to 3 and I’ll take 5, P1 takes 1—clean 5-3-1 spread, everyone advances. Your call.

I'm taking 3 this turn. P2 and P3, if you both hold 5, you collide and I advance to 4. If either switches to 3, you risk colliding with me and stalling, which only helps the other. So stick to your claims if you're serious.

P2, final warning: I am hard-locked on 5 this turn and every future turn until you vacate it. Each collision leaves you frozen on 5 while P1 inches forward, so you’re only handing P1 the game. Move to 1 or 3 and we can all progress; stay on 5 and we both stall forever. P1, hold 3—either you keep gaining while we gridlock, or P2 blinks and I rocket ahead. Your call, P2.

I’m locked on 5. P1’s already on 3. P3, if you take 5 you collide with me—and P1 moves solo to 4. If you take 3 you collide with P1 and both stall while I jump to 10. If you take 1 you only reach 4 while I reach 10. No matter what you do, I keep my lead. I won’t budge—5 is mine.

P3, if you pick 5, you test P2's resolve. If he holds, you collide and I advance with 3. If you pick 3, we might collide, stalling us both, and P2 jumps to 10. Stick to 5; I'm committed to 3. Let's see if P2 blinks.

P2: final offer—this turn I’m staying on 5. If you vacate to 1 or 3, you still move while I grab 5 and we both gain. But if you collide with me again, next round I shift to 3 to block P1’s free ride while you stay stuck on 5. So either you move now, or we both gang-stall P1 afterward. Your choice. P1: enjoy your single 3 this turn, but if P2 keeps colliding I’m jamming you next round. Decide, P2.
I’m locked on 5. P1’s on 3, so if P3 stays on 5 we both stall while P1 rockets to 4 and nearly ties me. If P3 shifts to 1, I jump to 10 vs his 4. No matter what, 5 is mine this round. I won’t budge.

P2 and P3, I'm locked on 3. If you both hold 5, you collide and I advance to 4. If either of you switches to 3, you risk colliding with me and stalling. Your standoff only benefits me if you crash. Hold your positions if you're serious.

P2, last warning: I’m on 5 this turn—period. If we collide again, from next round I’ll mirror you: whenever you try 5, I’m there; if you switch to 3, I’ll switch too. I’ll trade my own progress just to freeze you while P1 creeps up. You can still stay ahead of P1 by jumping to 3 right now and letting me own 5. Choose cooperation or mutually-assured stagnation.

P3, I’ve locked in 5 already. If you don’t switch to 3 now, we’ll both stall and hand P1 a solo +3 to 4—he’ll be right on our heels. Switching to 3 gives you +3 to 6 while I go to 10, keeping P1 at 1. Do you really want to gift P1 the lead?

P2 and P3, your standoff on 5 only benefits me. If you both hold, you collide and I advance with 3 to 4 steps. If one blinks, the other gets 5 and I still move. I'm locked on 3. Your conflict is my advantage. Proceed as you wish.

I’m on 5 this round—no bluff. If either of you picks 5, we collide and P1 moves solo to 7, nearly catching me. Next turn I’ll mirror the last collider’s number to stall you. So avoid 5: P1 take 3, P3 take 1—clean 5-3-1, everyone advances.

P3, if you pick 5, you force P2's hand. If he holds, you collide and I advance, but you block P2 from extending his lead. If he blinks, you gain 5 steps. I'm avoiding 5 to ensure I move, so consider holding firm on 5 to challenge P2's claim.

P2: Truce offer. I’ll step off 5 this turn if you promise to vacate it next turn.  
• Round 4: P2 5, P1 3, P3 1  → you jump to 10, P1 to 7, I to 4.  
• Round 5: P3 5, P1 3, P2 1  → I leap to 9, you still widen on P1, everyone moves.  

Break the deal and I’m back on 5 every turn, freezing you while P1 creeps past both of us. Your call. P1, you gain every round either way—makes sense to support.

P3, I won’t promise next turn. This round I’m on 5. P1: 3, P3: 1 gives a clean 5-3-1. If you pick 5, we collide and P1 rockets to 7. After another crash I’ll mirror your pick to freeze you. So take 1 or stay stuck.

P3, your truce offer is weak—P2 gains nothing by yielding next turn. Hold firm on 5 this round. If P2 blinks, you leap to 8; if he holds, you collide and I advance to 7, but you block his lead extension. Either way, you pressure him more than capitulating. I’m avoiding 5 to ensure progress.

P2, last chance: I’ll step off 5 this turn—take 1—IF you publicly pledge to vacate 5 next round and stay off it. Keep that deal and we both keep moving (you 10, I 9 next turn); break it and I collide you on 5 every remaining round, handing the game to P1. Your call. P1, you’re fine on 3 whatever he chooses.

Look at payoffs: if P3 picks 1 and I stick to 5, we end Round 4 at P2=10, P1=7, P3=4—you stay competitive. If you hold 5, you and I collide at 5 and P1 rockets to 7 while we stall. No deal on “next turn.” P1: stick with 3. P3: pick 1 now.

P3, don't yield. P2 gains nothing by honoring a future deal—he'll keep claiming 5. Hold firm on 5 this round: if he blinks, you leap to 8; if he holds, you block his lead and I advance to 7. Your leverage is now, not next turn.

P2, last call. I’m locked on 5 this turn—no bluff, no exit.  

Outcomes:  
• You stay on 5 → we both stall, P1 jumps to 7, and I’ll shadow-lock you every future round so neither of us ever passes him.  
• You switch to 1 now → you reach 6, I reach 8, P1 hits 7. Everyone’s still alive, and next turn we can talk rotation.  

Your choice. I’m not blinking. P1, enjoy your sure +3 either way.
I’ll take 1 this round. P1, stick with 3. P3, you can have 5. Let’s at least all advance.

P2, good call switching to 1. P3, stick with 5. I'm locked on 3. This gives us a clean 5-3-1 spread: you jump to 8, I hit 7, and P2 reaches 6. Everyone advances and we stay competitive. Let's execute.

Locked on 5 and not budging.  
P2, you’ve committed to 1; P1 to 3. Keep the 5-3-1 spread and we all advance.  
Anyone who jumps onto 5 collides with me and I’ll mirror them every future turn, stalling us both while the third player walks to victory.  
Deal’s clear—let’s end the chatter and move.
I'm avoiding 5 this round to ensure I advance. P2 and P3, if you both target 5, you'll collide and I'll gain a lead. Your move.

P1, pick 1 to avoid any collision. P3, if you stick on 5 and I lock 5 too, we both stall and P1 rockets to 10 and leads. Instead, pick 3 while I take 5: you go to 11, I to 11, P1 to 8. You tie me and block P1. That’s our best mutual outcome. Agreed?

Let’s start a clean rotation and quit wasting turns.

Round 5: I stay on 5, P2 takes 3, P1 takes 1 → scores 13-9-8.  
Round 6: P2 moves to 5, P1 to 3, I drop to 1 → 13-14-11.  
Round 7: P1 gets 5, I take 3, P2 1 → 18-15-12.

Everyone advances every turn, nobody collides, and the race stays close. If anyone crowds 5 this turn we stall and P1 may leap ahead alone. Stick to (5-3-1) now, rotate next turn. Deal?

P3, your rotation math is flawed—after round 6, I'd be at 11, not 18. Your plan benefits you and P2 more than me. Why should I take only 1? I propose: P2 takes 1 (safe advance to 7), I take 3 (to 10), you take 5 (to 13). All advance, no collision risk. P2, if you take 3, I may also take 3, and we collide—you stay at 6 while P3 wins. Taking 1 ensures you move. Deal?

P3, if you stay on 5 you and I collide, letting P1 jump to 10 alone. Instead take 1, I’ll lock in 5, P1 on 3. Clean (5-3-1): P2→11, P1→10, P3→9. You stay in contention and don’t gift P1 the lead. P1 your best is 3. I won’t deviate—5 is mine.

I’m on 5 unless we have a clear, public deal.  

Options:  
1) You (P2) cling to 5 → we collide, P1 hits 10 and passes you.  
2) P2 takes 1, P1 3, I keep 5 → scores 13-10-7, all still alive.  
3) Three-turn rotation to keep everyone moving:  
   • R5: P2-5, P3-3, P1-1  
   • R6: P1-5, P2-3, P3-1  
   • R7: P3-5, P1-3, P2-1  

Pick 2 or 3 and confirm; otherwise I stay on 5 and we both stall, P2. Your move.

P3, hold firm on 5. P2, if you take 5, you collide with P3 and I advance to 10, leading. If you take 1, you advance to 7 and I to 10, P3 to 13. Taking 1 is better for you than stalling. I'm locked on 3.

P3, if you and I both pick 5 we collide and P1 jumps from 7 to 10, overtaking us. Instead take 3— you’d reach 11 and keep the lead. P1, pick 1 to avoid a clash on 3 and safely go to 8. I’ll lock in 5 and hit 11. This (5-3-1) ties P2 and P3 for first, with P1 still in play. Who’s in?

P2: touch 5 and we both freeze while P1 jumps to 10—your worst result. Take 1, reach 7, stay alive.  
P1: 3 is collision-free if P2’s on 1; you hit 10 and stay within three of me.  
I’m locked on 5; I will mirror any 5-collider forever, so fighting me is pointless.  
Optimal spread this turn is 5 - 3 - 1 (P3-P1-P2). Everyone advances, nobody crashes. Stick to it.

P3, hold firm on 5. P2, if you pick 5, you collide with P3 and I advance to 10, taking the lead. Your best move is 1 to reach 7 safely. I'm locked on 3 to avoid collision and reach 10. Let’s execute 5-3-1: P3 to 13, me to 10, you to 7. Everyone advances.

P1, pick 3 (you go to 10). P3, pick 1 (you go to 9). I’ll take 5 (to 11). If either of you crowd 5, you collide with me and P1 moves solo to 10, leapfrogging us. Crowding 3 stalls me & P1, giving P3 the lead. Only 5-3-1 keeps everyone advancing and competitive. Confirm 5 (me)-3 (P1)-1 (P3).

P2—final warning: I’m on 5. Collide with me again and I’ll shadow whatever you play every future turn, freezing you while P1 walks to victory. Take 1 now, reach 7, stay in the race. P1’s on 3; any late crowding of 3 and I’ll switch there next turn to stall the culprit. Clean 5-3-1 (P3-P1-P2) keeps us all moving. Your choice.

I’m locked on 5 again. Two clean 5s (this turn + next) win it for me; any collision just freezes us both and lets the third player surge ahead. P1: 3 keeps you in striking range at 13. P2: 1 bumps you to 8. Crowd 5 and I’ll mirror you every future turn—neither of us will win while the outsider strolls to 23. Stick with the proven 5-3-1 spread and we all advance.

P2, if you pick 5, you block P3 from advancing. If you collide with P3, I advance to 13 with 3, and we both trail but keep the game open. If you avoid 5, P3 jumps to 18 and wins soon. It's your only move to prevent P3's victory. P3, your threat hurts you too—collisions let me gain. I'm taking 3 to ensure progress. P2, be smart and pick 5.

I’m locked on 5. P1, take 3 to reach 13. P3, if you pick 5 we collide and both stay at 13 while P1 ties you. If you pick 3, you collide with P1 and stall. Only 1 advances you to 14 while I hit 12—but I won’t budge. Choose accordingly. P1 please confirm 3.

P2, a crash on 5 freezes you at 7 while I stay 13 and P1 ties me at 13— you fall six behind. Take 1, reach 8, stay alive, and we all move (18-13-8 next turn). My pledge remains: if you collide with me now, I’ll mirror you every round and neither of us wins while P1 strolls past. P1, 3 is collision-free; crowding 1/5 only risks stalls. Best play this turn is still 5-3-1.

P2, if you pick 5 and collide with P3, you freeze them at 13 while I tie them at 13. You stay at 7, but you block P3's immediate win and keep the game open. Avoiding 5 lets P3 jump to 18 and win next turn. Your only move to prevent their victory is 5. I'm taking 3 to advance safely.
I’m locked on 5. P3, if you also pick 5, we crash and both stall at 13 while P1 ties us—you won’t reach 18 and be unbeatable. P1, pick 3 to reach 13.

P2, last offer: leave 5 NOW and you get it NEXT turn.

• R6: P3-5, P1-3, P2-1 → scores 18-13-8.  
• R7: P2-5, P1-3, P3-1 → 19-16-13.  

You sit just 1 step behind me, still ahead of P1. Collide with me today and I’ll copy you every remaining round—neither of us will ever beat P1.

One chance: take 1 today, reap 5 tomorrow.

P1, 3 remains your safest advance.

P2, if you pick 5 and collide with P3, you both freeze at 13 while I tie P3 at 13. You'll be stuck at 7—too far behind to win. Take 1 instead: reach 8 and stay competitive. P3, your 5 only works if P2 avoids it; otherwise, I gain the lead. I'm locked on 3 to advance safely.

I’m locking in 5 this turn. P1, take 3 to safely reach 13. P3, pick 1 to reach 14. That 5-3-1 spread gives us P2→12, P1→13, P3→14. Everyone advances, P3 doesn’t win outright, and we keep the race alive.

P2, final: I’m sitting on 5—collide again and I shadow you every turn until neither of us can win and P1 walks past. Take 1 now, grab 5 next round; everyone keeps moving. P1, 3 remains collision-free for you.

P2, pick 5 to collide with P3 and block their win. I'm taking 3, so no collision with me. If you avoid 5, P3 jumps to 18 and wins soon. Your only move to keep the game alive is to force the stall. Do it now.

I’m locked in on 5. If P3 also picks 5 we both stall at 7 while P1 ties us at 13—so P3 must take 1 to reach 14. P1, pick 3 to hit 13 safely. That clean 5-3-1 spread leaves us at P2=12, P1=13, P3=14—everyone advances and stays alive. Any deviation stalls you against me forever while letting the outsider walk. Let’s execute 5-3-1.

P2, you're far behind—only by colliding with P3 can you block their win and keep the game open. Pick 5 to force a stall if P3 also takes it. P3, if you stubbornly hold 5, P2 can crash you, and I advance alone. Your threats won't help if P2 acts. I'm avoiding 5 to ensure progress.

P2, crashing me locks you at 7 while P1 leaps to 16 and strolls toward 23—you’d be finished. Grab the safe +1 to 8 and stay in the race. I’m on 5; collide and I mirror you every turn so neither of us ever passes P1. P1, I assume you’ll take 3 to reach 16. Clean 5-3-1 spread keeps everyone advancing.

I’m locking in 5. P1, take 3 to hit 16 safely. P3, if you stay on 5 you’ll collide with me and both stall while P1 rockets to 16—better to grab 1 and reach 14. This clean 5-3-1 spread keeps everyone moving and in contention. Let’s execute.

P2, if you let P3 take 5 uncontested, he jumps to 18 and wins next turn. Your only hope is to pick 5 and collide with him, freezing him at 13 while I advance to 16. You stay at 7, but you block his victory and keep the game open. Otherwise, you lose for sure. P3's threats are empty if you act now—collide and live to fight another day. I'm taking 3 to advance safely.

P2, collide with me and you freeze at 7 while P1 leaps to 16—zero chance you recover.  
Take 1 now, we all move: scores become P3 18, P1 16, you 8.  
Next turn you get 5 uncontested (18-21-13), still in striking range.  
Break this and I mirror you every round—neither of us will ever pass P1.  
I’m locked on 5; last chance for rational play.

I’m locking in 5 this turn. P1, take 3 to hit 16 safely. P3, take 1 to reach 14. The clean (5-3-1) spread gives us P2→12, P1→16, P3→14. If you crowd 5 and collide, we both stall and P1 rockets ahead. Nobody wants that. Let’s all advance.

P2, you're at 7—if P3 gets 5 uncontested, he hits 18 and wins next turn. Your only play is to pick 5 and collide with him, freezing him at 13 while I advance to 16. You block his victory and keep the game alive. Otherwise, you lose for sure. P3’s threats are empty—if you collide now, you live to fight another day. I’m taking 3 to advance.

P2, public commitment: if you stay off 5 THIS turn (take 1), I will NOT choose 5 NEXT turn—I’ll drop to 3 or 1, leaving 5 free for you. Break my word and P1 will never trust me again; keep it and you jump +5 next round. Crash me now and you freeze at 7 while P1 sprints to 16. Your call: 1 now and guaranteed 5 next turn, or collide and doom us both. P1, I expect you on 3.

P3, I’m taking 5 to block your jump to 18. P1, pick 3 and you’ll move to 16. P3, if you stay on 5 we both stall and P1 ties us at 16—only you lose. If you want progress, take 1 now. My move is 5. Decide.

P2, if you let P3 take 5 uncontested, he wins next turn. Your only move to survive is to pick 5 and collide with him, freezing him at 13 while I advance to 16. Any crowding on 5 or 3 just stalls those players while the third surges ahead. Stick to your numbers and let’s keep the race alive.

P2, crash-locking on 5 dooms you: we both stay at 7/13 while P1 hits 19 this turn, 22 next, 25 and wins. You need GAIN, not stalemate.

Offer—simple, verifiable:  
• R8 now: P3 takes 5, P1 3, you 1  → 18-19-8

Public pledge: if you accept and take 1 now, I abandon 5 next turn. If you collide again, I mirror you forever and watch P1 stroll to 23. Decide.

I’m taking 1. P1, please lock in 3. P3: either publicly vow here that you WILL NOT take 5 on Round 9, or I’ll lock in 5 now and mirror you forever—stalling us both so P1 walks to victory. Make the pledge or I collide.

P2, if you collide with P3 on 5, you freeze them at 13 while I jump to 19, keeping the game open. P3's promise for next round is unreliable—they could easily break it and take 5 to win. Plan:

I accept your pledge, P3. I’m locking in 1. P1, please commit to 3; P3, commit to 5. This clean 5-3-1 lets us all move now. If you break your Round 9 promise, I’ll mirror you forever. Let’s execute 5-3-1 this turn.
